text: We did drop deicer during the last storm and our crews are out currently, dropping deicer today on the city’s main streets. However, deicers are not melting agents. They minimize snow & ice from bonding to the pavement surface.
text_html: We did drop deicer during the last storm and our crews are out currently, dropping deicer today on the city’s main streets. However, deicers are not melting agents. They minimize snow & ice from bonding to the pavement surface.

text: Deicers are not melting agents; they minimize snow and ice from bonding to the pavement surface. Deicer is most effective when traffic breaks up the snow, as that makes it easier to remove the snow with successive plow passes.
text_html: Deicers are not melting agents; they minimize snow and ice from bonding to the pavement surface. Deicer is most effective when traffic breaks up the snow, as that makes it easier to remove the snow with successive plow passes.

text: We did drop deicer during the last storm and our crews are out currently, dropping deicer today on the city’s main streets. However, deicers are not melting agents. They minimize snow & ice from bonding to the pavement surface.
text_html: We did drop deicer during the last storm and our crews are out currently, dropping deicer today on the city’s main streets. However, deicers are not melting agents. They minimize snow & ice from bonding to the pavement surface.

text: Deicers are not melting agents; they minimize snow and ice from bonding to the pavement surface. Deicer is most effective when traffic breaks up the snow, as that makes it easier to remove the snow with successive plow passes.
text_html: Deicers are not melting agents; they minimize snow and ice from bonding to the pavement surface. Deicer is most effective when traffic breaks up the snow, as that makes it easier to remove the snow with successive plow passes.

text: We actually received quite a bit of snow in a short amount of time and temps were extremely cold. Our deicer contains more than 90% chloride salts. It helps prevent snow & ice from bonding to the pavement, so it's easier to remove during plow passes. It also provides traction.
text_html: We actually received quite a bit of snow in a short amount of time and temps were extremely cold. Our deicer contains more than 90% chloride salts. It helps prevent snow & ice from bonding to the pavement, so it's easier to remove during plow passes. It also provides traction.

text: The biggest concern we heard from people on bikes this year was about drivers parking in bike lanes. We think positive reinforcement & educating drivers to not block a bike lane when they load/park is also your reward! This way, you can get around the city safely & comfortably.

text: Help us keep Denver clean from drain to stream! It's as easy as picking up your dog's . When it rains, stormwater runoff could pick-up that residue, which is taken to our inlets & eventually the river. Request FREE pet waste bags on our website: http://ow.ly/J3dX50uXA1u pic.twitter.com/Fdt5triLlc

text: Vehicle speed influences both the risk of being involved in a crash as well as the severity of injuries that result from a crash. Speeding is a factor in 53% of fatalities in Denver, so lowering the speed limit in these areas is an important step.
text_html: Vehicle speed influences both the risk of being involved in a crash as well as the severity of injuries that result from a crash. Speeding is a factor in 53% of fatalities in Denver, so lowering the speed limit in these areas is an important step.

text: No. Pre-treating is not recommended when a storm comes in as rain first, as rain will wash the material away. Pre-treating doesn't prevent ice from forming, but serves to prevent ice from bonding to the street. Pre-treating would not have changed the condition of streets today.

text: Another freshly paved street in the books! This is Green Street from 49th to 50th. It received a Hot-In-Place roadway treatment, which heats the top inch of existing asphalt pavement & mixes this with new asphalt. The pavement will last about 8 to 10 years! pic.twitter.com/cG8j9mcQk9
text_html: Another freshly paved street in the books! This is Green Street from 49th to 50th. It received a Hot-In-Place roadway treatment, which heats the top inch of existing asphalt pavement & mixes this with new asphalt. The pavement will last about 8 to 10 years! pic.twitter.com/cG8j9mcQk9

text: Another freshly paved street in the books! This is Green Street from 49th to 50th. It received a Hot-In-Place roadway treatment, which heats the top inch of existing asphalt pavement & mixes this with new asphalt. The pavement will last about 8 to 10 years! pic.twitter.com/cG8j9mcQk9
text_html: Another freshly paved street in the books! This is Green Street from 49th to 50th. It received a Hot-In-Place roadway treatment, which heats the top inch of existing asphalt pavement & mixes this with new asphalt. The pavement will last about 8 to 10 years! pic.twitter.com/cG8j9mcQk9

text: Yes, we did recently retime the traffic signals on York & Josephine Streets from 37th to 6th Avenues. The signal retiming actually improves traffic flow, providing 700 fewer hours of vehicle travel along both corridors per day. So, you may have pulled up at the end of the cycle.

text: The solid deicer, Ice Slicer, is a naturally-mined product from Utah & more than 90% chloride salts. Its red color comes from 60+ trace minerals also naturally found in the deicer. The product helps prevent snow and ice from bonding to the pavement and can provide some traction.
text_html: The solid deicer, Ice Slicer, is a naturally-mined product from Utah & more than 90% chloride salts. Its red color comes from 60+ trace minerals also naturally found in the deicer. The product helps prevent snow and ice from bonding to the pavement and can provide some traction.

text: Bike lanes that are not protected are handled by the big plows, as they try to clear snow from curb to curb. Ice reported in these types of bike lanes are treated as ice complaints. Street Maintenance will send a crew with larger equipment to blade the ice. (2/2)
